title: 442-C
statement: C. Artem and Arraytime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutArtem has an array ofnpositive integers. Artem decided to play with it. The game consists ofnmoves. Each move goes like this. Artem chooses some element of the array and removes it. For that, he getsmin(a,b)points, whereaandbare numbers that were adjacent with the removed number. If the number doesn't have an adjacent number to the left or right, Artem doesn't get any points.After the element is removed, the two parts of the array glue together resulting in the new array that Artem continues playing with. Borya wondered what maximum total number of points Artem can get as he plays this game.InputThe first line contains a single integern(1 ≤n≤ 5·105)— the number of elements in the array. The next line containsnintegersai(1 ≤ai≤ 106)— the values of the array elements.OutputIn a single line print a single integer — the maximum number of points Artem can get.ExamplesInput53 1 5 2 6Output11Input51 2 3 4 5Output6Input51 100 101 100 1Output102

processed.result: You are given an array of $n$ positive integers.  You can repeatedly remove one element from the array.  When you remove an element, you get points equal to the minimum of the values of its two adjacent elements. If an element has no adjacent elements, you get 0 points. What is the maximum number of points you can get by repeatedly removing elements from the array?
You are given a list of numbers. You can repeatedly remove one number from the list and get points based on the values of the numbers next to it.  What is the maximum number of points you can get?
